title: I need to identify this font sans sherif - Art deco, can you help me ?
author: Louis XIV

comments.content:
Sonrisa Medium is close (though the thin strokes on the Rs are a bit too thick, not in the same position, and aren't curved):  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/castletype/sonrisa/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414205106/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/castletype/sonrisa/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/castletype/sonrisa/")

General feel, though not a close match:  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/peignot/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414205106/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/peignot/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/peignot/") (demi)  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/t26/bauer-house/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414205106/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/t26/bauer-house/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/t26/bauer-house/")  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/jnlevine/stylette/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414205106/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/jnlevine/stylette/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/jnlevine/stylette/")

Saya Semi Sans Medium or Bold is fairly close [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontyou/saya-semisans-fy/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414205106/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontyou/saya-semisans-fy/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontyou/saya-semisans-fy/") Also Minerva Modern [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/t26/minerva/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414205106/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/t26/minerva/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/t26/minerva/") and GHEA Narek -- particularly if the width is compressed to 66%

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414205106im_/http:/typophile.com/files/GHEANarekBoldAtWidth66Percent_6581.jpg)
  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/armtype/ghea-narek/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414205106/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/armtype/ghea-narek/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/armtype/ghea-narek/") Have not been able to find a perfect match with a French thick and thin sans with this Art Deco R from circa 1930.

Washington [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/typeassociates/washington/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414205106/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/typeassociates/washington/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/typeassociates/washington/") has a closer R to ARRIVÉE than any of the suggestions so far, and has about the same height to width ratio as ARRIVÉE , but it is not a thick and thin font.  
If the objective is to replicate the letters Washington might be the best candidate for editing by thickening some of the strokes. Mighty Tuxedo -- particularly the Short Caps [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/astigmatic/mighty-tuxedo-aoe/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414205106/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/astigmatic/mighty-tuxedo-aoe/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/astigmatic/mighty-tuxedo-aoe/") is similar to Washington as a candidate for editing, but you would have to start with its thicker stokes and thin them as required. If the objective is to do a full uppercase alphabet suitable for compressed signage like ARRIVÉE I would start with Mighty Tuxedo.  
Don

A different approach would be to start with Roxy Medium

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414205106im_/http:/typophile.com/files/RoxyMedInUse_3814.jpg)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontbureau/roxy/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414205106/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontbureau/roxy/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontbureau/roxy/") which looks quite similar to ARRIVÉE and edit the R to match.  
Don
